title: 60-62 Kent Street, Millers Point
text:
60-62 Kent Street, Millers Point are heritage-listed <a href="terrace%20house">terrace house</a>s located at 60-62 Kent Street, in the inner city <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> suburb of <a href="Millers%20Point%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Millers Point</a> in the <a href="City%20of%20Sydney">City of Sydney</a> local government area of <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a>, Australia. It was added to the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20State%20Heritage%20Register">New South Wales State Heritage Register</a> on 2 April 1999.
History.
Millers Point is one of the earliest areas of European settlement in Australia, and a focus for maritime activities. Terrace housing built during the 1860s. First tenanted by the <a href="Housing%20NSW">NSW Department of Housing</a> in 1982.
Description.
A simple well proportioned two-storey Victorian terrace house with two bedrooms. Features include a cantilevered <a href="balcony">balcony</a> over footpath, a corrugated iron <a href="veranda">veranda</a>h painted in wide stripes, <a href="french%20doors">french doors</a> with <a href="fanlight">fanlight</a> on upper storey, panelled front door with fanlight and single window with slab sill and shutters on ground floor. Storeys: Two; Construction: Painted rendered masonry, <a href="corrugated%20galvanised%20iron">corrugated galvanised iron</a> roof. Timber framed balcony with decorative iron lace balcony. Painted timber joinery. Style: <a href="Australian%20residential%20architectural%20styles%23Filigree">Victorian Filigree</a>.
The external condition of the property is good.
Modifications and dates.
External: Some timber joinery is new.
Heritage listing.
As at 23 November 2000, this 1860s terrace forms part of a cohesive streetscape element.
It is part of the <a href="Millers%20Point%20Conservation%20Area">Millers Point Conservation Area</a>, an intact residential and maritime precinct. It contains residential buildings and civic spaces dating from the 1830s and is an important example of 19th century adaptation of the landscape.
60-62 Kent Street, Millers Point was listed on the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20State%20Heritage%20Register">New South Wales State Heritage Register</a> on 2 April 1999.
